items.title: Yemen airport shut down amid Saudi-UAE rift

featured_image.name: Yemen’s separatist STC accuses Saudi Arabia of bombing forces along border

items.description:
Yemen's Aden International Airport shut down on Thursday as escalating tensions between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates spilled into civil aviation, stranding hundreds of passengers and underscoring a deepening crisis between the Gulf powers[1][2][3]. The closure came amid a broader confrontation over control of Yemen's resource-rich eastern provinces, where Saudi-backed forces launched military operations on Friday that killed at least seven people[4][5][6].

Air traffic at the airport—Yemen's main international gateway outside Houthi control—was halted after Yemen's internationally recognized government, backed by Riyadh, imposed new restrictions on flights to and from the UAE[1][2]. Rather than comply, Yemen's transport minister, aligned with the UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council, ordered a complete shutdown[1][2]. Passengers crowded the terminal awaiting updates, with some traveling for urgent medical treatment left in limbo[7][8].

The aviation dispute reflects a wider rift that has fractured the Saudi-led coalition fighting in Yemen. On Friday, Saudi warplanes conducted seven airstrikes on an STC military camp in Hadramout province's Al-Khasah area, killing at least seven and wounding more than 20, according to STC officials[4][5][6]. The strikes came as Saudi-backed forces launched what they termed a "peaceful operation" to retake positions seized by the STC during its December offensive[9][10].

items.title: Trump says US will 'come to their rescue' if Iran kills protesters
items.description: President Donald Trump says the United States is "locked and loaded" to respond if Iran kills protesters, prompting Tehran to warn that intervention would destabilise the region.

items.title: 87 runaway stars mapped to trace Milky Way's dark matter

featured_image.name: Runaway Stars Help Astronomers Trace Dark Matter Distribution ...

items.description:
Astronomers from China have identified 87 hypervelocity stars racing through the Milky Way fast enough to escape the galaxy's gravitational pull, offering a new method to map the distribution of dark matter across our cosmic home. The research, published in The Astrophysical Journal and announced this week, uses these stellar runaways as tracers to probe the galaxy's invisible structure[1][2][3][4].

The team, led by Haozhu Fu of Peking University, focused on RR Lyrae stars, ancient pulsating giants that serve as reliable distance indicators due to their predictable brightness patterns[1][3]. By analyzing data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, the Chinese LAMOST telescope, and the European Space Agency's Gaia satellite, researchers sifted through more than 135,000 candidate stars before identifying the most reliable hypervelocity examples[1][3].

Seven of the discovered stars are moving at tangential velocities exceeding 800 kilometers per second—well above the roughly 550 km/s needed to break free from the Milky Way at the sun's position[1][3][5]. According to Phys.org, all 87 stars exceed the galaxy's escape velocity in their tangential component, suggesting many will eventually drift into intergalactic space[1][2].

items.title: Scientists create self-powered quantum maser with stable microwave signals

featured_image.name: Quantum technology moves from lab to life, but widespread use ...

items.description:
Scientists at TU Wien and the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology have demonstrated the first self-induced superradiant quantum maser, a discovery that could reshape precision technologies from GPS navigation to medical imaging.

Published in Nature Physics, the research shows how quantum particles can spontaneously cooperate to generate stable, long-lived microwave signals without external power, overturning previous assumptions about how quantum systems behave[1][2][3]. The team coupled nitrogen-vacancy centers in diamond—tiny atomic defects containing electron spins—to a microwave cavity, where they observed an unexpected phenomenon: after an initial burst of energy, the system produced a sustained train of coherent microwave pulses lasting up to a millisecond[2][4].

"What's remarkable is that the seemingly messy interactions between spins actually fuel the emission," said Dr. Wenzel Kersten, first author of the study, in a press statement. "The system organizes itself, producing an extremely coherent microwave signal from the very disorder that usually destroys it"[1][3].

items.title: Eurozone manufacturing hits nine-month low on German decline

featured_image.name: German manufacturing sector faces sharp decline in new orders, PMI shows

items.description:
The eurozone's manufacturing sector closed 2025 on a downbeat note, with activity contracting at the sharpest pace in nine months as Germany's industrial woes spread across the currency bloc, according to final data released Friday.

The HCOB Eurozone Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index, compiled by S&P Global, fell to 48.8 in December from 49.6 in November, marking the deepest contraction since March and signaling deteriorating factory conditions across the region[1][2][3]. A reading below 50 indicates contraction. After nine consecutive months of growth, production volumes declined for the first time since February, while new orders dropped at their fastest pace in almost a year[4][2].

items.title: Rescue operations underway after coal mine collapse
items.description: One man is in hospital and another is missing following an incident at a Central Queensland coal mine.

items.title: Dollar starts 2026 weak after worst year since 2017

featured_image.name: Dollar makes a soft start to 2026 after sharpest drop in 8 ...

items.description:
The U.S. dollar opened 2026 on a feeble note Friday, struggling near multi-month lows after posting its sharpest annual decline in eight years, as narrowing interest rate differentials and mounting uncertainty about Federal Reserve leadership weigh on the currency.

The dollar index, which measures the greenback against six major currencies, traded at 98.2 on the first trading day of the year after registering a 9.4% decline in 2025—its steepest drop since 2017[1][2][3]. The euro held steady at $1.1752 following a 13.5% surge last year, while sterling traded at $1.3474 after climbing 7.7% in 2025[1][4]. Both currencies posted their strongest annual gains since 2017[1][4].

items.title: Google, SpaceX plan AI data centers in orbit

featured_image.name: SpaceX eyes possible record IPO. What's behind the hype

items.description:
Google, SpaceX, and a host of technology leaders are pursuing an ambitious vision to establish data centers in orbit, aiming to solve artificial intelligence's insatiable appetite for energy while sidestepping earthbound constraints.

Google announced Project Suncatcher in November, with plans to launch two prototype satellites in early 2027 that will test AI hardware powered by continuous solar energy[1][2][3]. CEO Sundar Pichai told Fox News that building extraterrestrial data centers will be "normal" within a decade[1][4]. Meanwhile, startup Starcloud made history in December by successfully training an AI model—Google's Gemma—aboard its satellite, marking the first time a large language model operated in space[5][6].

SpaceX confirmed in December it is preparing for a possible 2026 initial public offering that could raise more than $30 billion, with proceeds earmarked for "AI data centers in space," according to chief financial officer Bret Johnsen[7][8][9]. At an $800 billion valuation, the company is positioning itself as a key player in orbital computing infrastructure[8][10]. Tesla CEO Elon Musk has said space data centers would be "the cheapest way to train AI" within five years[1][2].

items.title: What we learned from Donald Trump's wide-ranging health interview
items.description: US President Donald Trump says he regrets undergoing advanced imagery on his heart and abdomen because of the "ammunition" it handed his critics, but has once more defended his "perfect" health.

items.title: Ski resort fire witnesses recall how tragic Crans-Montana blaze unfolded
items.description: As the resort town of Crans-Montana reels from the news of a tragic fire at a New Year's Eve party, a witness recalls hearing screams and seeing people covered in blood in the aftermath of the bar blaze.

items.title: Asian stocks rally as Baidu soars on AI chip spinoff plans

featured_image.name: Exclusive: Baidu's Kunlunxin, valued at close to $3 billion, eyes Hong Kong IPO, sources say

items.description:
Asian markets and precious metals kicked off 2026 with strong gains on Friday as investors embraced technology stocks and continued piling into gold and silver following their record-breaking 2025 performance.

Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index surged 2.2% to 26,189.79 in the first trading session of the year, led by a rally in technology shares[1][2][3]. Chinese search giant Baidu jumped 7.5% after announcing plans to spin off its artificial intelligence chip division, Kunlunxin, for a Hong Kong initial public offering expected in early 2027[2][3][4]. E-commerce leader Alibaba rose 3.2%[2][3].

The tech rally reflected sustained investor enthusiasm for AI-related companies. Biren Technologies, a Shanghai-based GPU developer, began trading in Hong Kong on Friday after raising $624 million in what became the city's first IPO of 2026[5][6]. The company's shares surged 80% following the debut[7], underscoring strong demand for Chinese semiconductor firms as the country seeks alternatives to U.S. chips amid export restrictions.

items.title: Hubble reveals sustained jet activity on interstellar comet

featured_image.name: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS shines in new images ahead of ...

items.description:
Interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS made its closest approach to Earth on December 19, 2025, offering astronomers an unprecedented opportunity to study material from beyond our solar system. The comet, discovered on July 1 by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System in Chile, passed within 270 million kilometers of Earth while traveling at 58 kilometers per second—making it the fastest interstellar object ever recorded[1][2][3][4].

New observations from the Hubble Space Telescope reveal sustained jet activity that challenges established models of cometary physics. Images captured on December 12 and 27 show twin jets of material erupting from the comet's nucleus in a pattern suggesting organized rotation rather than random outgassing[1][3][5][6]. According to International Business Times UK, these jets maintain collimation and coherence over extended periods—a phenomenon not anticipated in most comet models, as traditional comet jets typically become diffuse and disperse rapidly[1][3].

items.title: Rare celestial events to offer skywatchers extraordinary displays in 2026

featured_image.name: Why 2026 is your last chance to see the Northern Lights at their peak

items.description:
The new year promises a spectacular lineup of astronomical phenomena, with 2026 offering skywatchers an array of eclipses, meteor showers, and supermoons not seen in years. From a total solar eclipse sweeping across the Arctic to the best Perseids meteor shower in more than a decade, the year ahead brings rare opportunities to witness the cosmos in action.

The year features 13 full moons, including three supermoons, two major eclipses visible from populated areas, and meteor showers with near-perfect viewing conditions[1][2][3][4][5][6]. Astronomers say 2026 presents one of the most compelling years for celestial observation in recent memory[4].

items.title: Six killed as Iran protests spread beyond Tehran

featured_image.name: Deaths reported during widening protests in Iran sparked by ailing economy

items.description:
At least six people have died as demonstrations over Iran's collapsing economy spread from Tehran to rural provinces, marking the deadliest unrest since the country's 2022 protest movement. The fatalities, which occurred between Wednesday night and Thursday evening, signal an escalation in tensions between Iranian authorities and protesters demanding relief from runaway inflation and currency depreciation[1][2][3][4].

Iranian authorities confirmed that a 21-year-old member of the Basij paramilitary force was killed late Wednesday in Kuhdasht, a city in western Lorestan province, with officials claiming he died "defending public order" as 13 other security personnel sustained injuries[3][5][6]. On Thursday, the semi-official Fars news agency reported five additional deaths across Lorestan and Chaharmahal and Bakhtiari provinces, including two people killed in Lordegan and three in Azna during clashes with security forces[3][7][8].

The protests erupted Sunday after shopkeepers in Tehran's historic Grand Bazaar shuttered their businesses in response to the rial plunging to approximately 1.45 million per U.S. dollar, down from 820,000 rials just one year ago[9][10][11]. According to Iran's Statistical Center, annual inflation reached 42.2 percent in December, with food prices soaring 72 percent year-over-year[9][12]. The demonstrations have since expanded to multiple cities including Isfahan, Shiraz, Mashhad, Hamadan, and Zanjan, with students joining merchants in the streets[13][10][14].

items.title: China's anti-pollution crusade linked to Australian bushfires
items.description: As China caps off a historic clean-up of its smog and air pollution, the clearer air is helping temperatures rise to new records. Now, researchers are linking that change to hotter and drier conditions in Australia.

items.title: China's beef tariffs aren't about Australia
items.description: Beijing's new measures are aimed at trying to rein in an Australian surge and manage local growth, rather than a direct target on Australia.

items.title: Khawaja's on-field brilliance pales in comparison to his true impact
items.description: Before his debut in 2011, Australia had never seen a cricketer like Usman Khawaja and, thanks to his work on and off the field, he'll be followed by plenty more.

items.title: 'Everybody knows her': Sydney mother one of four drowning victims
items.description: The identity of one of four people who died in a cluster of drownings on the New South Wales coast in recent days has been confirmed as a Sydney hairdresser and mother.

items.description: Australia batter Usman Khawaja announces he will retire from international cricket after the fifth and final Ashes Test at the SCG, which starts on Sunday.

items.title: Easter Island researchers say giant statues 'walked' into position
items.description: A study using 11,600 aerial drone photos to map a mountainous quarry in 3D reveals more about how the island's famed stone sentinels were created and moved to their final resting places.

items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
